job_title: Account Strategist in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Google is very generous with the total compensation (TC), which is composed of:

1.) Highly competitive base salary depending on your "Level." 
2.) Annual bonus (40% of base) 
3.) Equity (front-loaded 33%/33%/22%/12%)
4.) Sign-on bonus
5.) Relocation package

Cool perks: Googleplex gym, free food (3 meals a day + snacks + drinks), 50% 401k matching up to $19,500, hybrid work model (MF at home, TWTH in office), PTO, education reimbursement, internet & phone reimbursement, massage chairs & nap pods, cool office spaces with different themed rooms (Harry Potter, etc.), bikes and scooters to get around campus 

Everyone at Google is intelligent, helpful, and friendly. The best part is diversity and inclusion. I've never felt safer being different, sharing unique ideas, and being myself at any other organization. 

The leaders and my peers constantly challenge me to grow in more ways than I can imagine. There are different programs for mentorship, which helped me discover my career path. I feel supported here, and the kindness of my team is genuine, and I feel like everyone wants to help each other.
cons: It's a big tech company, so it takes more time to make an impact vs. a tech start-up. There are politics and nuances to getting promoted, but that's a given with any big corporation.

cons:

* Performance reviews are stressful and take up a large portion of time throughout the year and some departments do have a curve so even if you are doing well, it might not be enough

review_title: 3 Stars for the Management, 5 for the Company
pros:
Great career mobility options.
Lots of smart people you can learn from and are willing to help you if you demonstrate that you can help yourself.
Countless resources to learn from if you take the time to search them out.
cons:
In my experience, the culture is the exact opposite of what leadership claims it is (customer first). Middle management in the Ad Sales / Ad Measurement Consulting org seem to only care about 1) hitting their quotas by whatever means possible and 2) padding their resume with shiny projects to get promoted (regardless of whether those projects had real impact).
Additionally, many of the middle managers are highly underskilled.
All of this results in a strong culture of pressure to put mediocre work out the door at high-speed so management can pad their performance reviews with accomplishments. By the time the results of mediocre work come to fruition, those outcomes are swept under the rug and the next shiny accomplishment is chased.

review_title: Amazing benefits and Great Team Environment
job_title: Technical Recruiter in New York, NY
pros: The company benefits are no joke -- they are the best in the market for experiences in-office and family-planning. It's a great company that cares about its employees and users. The 20% projects also give you an opportunity to expand your skillsets and try new things without the risk, which is why people end up staying so long. They are also the most diverse workforce I've ever been at, especially in the NY office. And, they take care of their employees during Bear Markets.
cons:
If you are someone who doesn't like to go into the office, the benefits may not feel very exceptional for you / you might feel some pressure to go into the office. 
Also, the social environment can be taxing for someone who likes to just be head-down working.

job_title: Software Engineer-III in New York, NY
pros:
- You'll work with very smart people
- The stock performs very well (generally)
- Decent work / life balance
- Great benefits
- Great stepping stone for your career
cons:
- RTO policy is stupid (cutting as much as 25% base salary for employees wanting to stay remote)
- Compensation no longer top of market (This has been the case since even before the pandemic. eg.) Stripe, Netflix, Instacart, The TradeDesk all pay much better)
- Lots of red tape and not much room for making impact
- There has been a noticeable shift in culture since the pandemic where you feel like a cog in a giant machine that doesn't care about you. Mass emails talking about policy, upper management out of touch with employees, and a common problem where you ask a question in chat and no one replies.
- Good luck getting in touch with an HR rep if you ever have an issue and actually need to talk to one

review_title: Good company (If you’re a fresh grad or want a stable life)
job_title: User Experience Designer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Hands down one of the best tech companies in the world. For a company this size, it’s very progressive and forward thinking. If you’re a fresh grad you’ll learn how to work within a system and learn from some of the best in the business. If you are a very capable person and are tired of grinding at a smaller company, Google is also a great place to cruise. You’ll get decently challenging projects without the stress of having to produce right away. If you’re looking for a big company with good pay, stability and flexibility. Look no further.
cons: If you’re looking for a more challenging job or want to be able to see your impact faster, this is not the place to be. If you prefer to grow into your role instead of being groomed for a role then you’ll have to look elsewhere. As progressive and flat as a big company can be, Google at the end of the day IS still A BIG COMPANY, you will inevitably feel like a cog in a giant machine just like being in any other big companies.

job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: Really good infrastructure for pretty much everything: Food, fitness, arts, games, maker spaces, working on the main Mountain View campus is probably the closest I can imagine to a utopian vision of a socialist society where there's a ton of stuff available for anyone to use.
cons: The actual work sucks. It's just a pointless treadmill of working on other people's fever dreams that get cancelled or shuffled around every 6 months. I quit because I realized if I stayed there any longer, I would have absolutely no actual work experience to point to if I ever wanted to leave and get hired anywhere else. The entire company hiring strategy is just to hire as many people as possible (lest another one of the tech giants picks them up), and let them try to figure out how to be useful (and then end up making 10 competing chat apps). But if you're looking for something well-compensated, stable, and with a lot of great perks, you can do a heck of a lot worse.

- Work-life balance varies a lot, but it's always better than Amazon in my experience

review_title: Great program to get into Google
pros:
- Free food and snacks
- Excellent benefits (Google gives you $10K per year if you max your 401K)
- Fun coworkers and positive working environment
- Flexible/Hybrid work opportunities
- Learn lots about Cloud and time/budget to attain professional certifications
- Explore both technical and non-technical work
cons:
- Your experience is very dependant on the team you end up rotating with, so mileage may vary. If you end up with a team without much work, you have to actively search around for things to do. On the other hand, if your team is slammed, you will have to learn to say no.

- Information is provided with little warning. The program can be changed on the fly, and you will not know where or in what role you will be placed until a week before it happens

- You begin as an L2, rather than the usual L3

- If you are set on being 100% technical, software engineering may be a better fit. You could try to transfer after this program but I think having software engineering experience at another company will be a better way into Google SWE.

pros:
I've worked on Chrome, and everyone on the team was on top of their game, very smart.
You could count on code reviews being thorough.
It is fascinating to observe Google from the inside, the culture, how things get done. The all-hands show with Larry and Sergey was amazing.
Health insurance was the best I've ever had.
cons:
The usual big company stuff: you do not  get to influence the big picture much, you are one of the 150K.  There are tasks to be done that you see no value in, they are just processes that need to be followed. 
The big question is, do you believe in Google's mission?  That they are good, doing the best they can, looking out for users, Google loves Google, believes that they are great, and if you find yourself disagreeing  with the Google way, you might get grumpy.

review_title: A decent place to work, that could be much better
pros:
Great coworkers
Decent pay
Maybe it will get better
cons:
The company is undervaluing this area. By working anywhere else in the country - Pittsburgh Pa, Rural Virginia -- even 40 miles West to Burlington, NC you would make more money. This does a disservice to the area. The company further claims it is trying to hire more HBCU graduates in this location... So cheapest location in the country, and trying to hire HBCU graduates. Not a good look. The News & Observer and Washington post have both issued articles "Google lowered its salaries in North Carolina. Now workers are protesting" and "Google employees protest company’s Durham wage policy. Here’s why they’re upset"

On a less key note, compared to other google offices, the office here seems surprisingly normal - more akin to your typical office location than you think of when you hear google office. Maybe this isn't a bad thing, but it shouldn't feel so targeted as making this a "discount" location.

pros:
I was here to improve my remote communication skills and technical communications skills. I was able to better communicate my issues and I have acquired several skills at this time.
Partly succeeded in acquiring the skill that I aspired to have.
cons: The things that I dislike about my current organization are, that we spend too much time and meetings, and things that could have been kept concise and to the point grow up into a long discussion.
